title: Psalms Chapter 22 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 22 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 22 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 22.

questions.question: According to Psalms 22:1, what is the opening cry of the Psalm of David?
options: My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?
The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want.
Bless the LORD, O my soul.
Give thanks unto the LORD, for he is good.
questions.correctAnswer: My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:1 opens with the cry, 'My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?' as spoken by David.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist say about God in Psalms 22:3?
options: Thou art holy, O thou that inhabitest the praises of Israel.
The LORD is my strength and my song.
God is a refuge for the oppressed.
The LORD is slow to anger and great in power.
questions.correctAnswer: Thou art holy, O thou that inhabitest the praises of Israel.
questions.explanation: In Psalms 22:3, God is described as holy and dwelling in the praises of Israel.

questions.question: Who does the Psalmist say trusted God and were delivered in Psalms 22:4?
options: Our fathers
The enemies
The kings
The shepherds
questions.correctAnswer: Our fathers
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:4 states that 'Our fathers trusted in thee: they trusted, and thou didst deliver them.'

questions.question: In Psalms 22:6, how does the Psalmist describe himself?
options: A worm, and no man
A lion among sheep
A mighty warrior
A shepherd of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: A worm, and no man
questions.explanation: The Psalmist describes himself as 'a worm, and no man; a reproach of men, and despised of the people' in Psalms 22:6.

questions.question: According to Psalms 22:8, what do the mockers say about the Psalmist's trust in the LORD?
options: He trusted on the LORD that he would deliver him.
He trusted in his own strength.
He trusted in the armies of Israel.
He trusted in the wisdom of men.
questions.correctAnswer: He trusted on the LORD that he would deliver him.
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:8 records the mockers saying, 'He trusted on the LORD that he would deliver him.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 22:12 say has compassed the Psalmist?
options: Many bulls, strong bulls of Bashan
A roaring sea
A multitude of locusts
A fiery furnace
questions.correctAnswer: Many bulls, strong bulls of Bashan
questions.explanation: The Psalmist says in Psalms 22:12, 'Many bulls have compassed me: strong bulls of Bashan have beset me round.'

questions.question: In Psalms 22:14, how does the Psalmist describe his heart?
options: Like wax; it is melted in the midst of my bowels
Like a stone; hard and unyielding
Like a lion; fierce and courageous
Like gold; pure and refined
questions.correctAnswer: Like wax; it is melted in the midst of my bowels
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:14 says, 'my heart is like wax; it is melted in the midst of my bowels.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 22:16, what have the assembly of the wicked done to the Psalmist?
options: They pierced my hands and my feet.
They crowned me with thorns.
They cast me into the fire.
They bound me in chains.
questions.correctAnswer: They pierced my hands and my feet.
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:16 states, 'the assembly of the wicked have inclosed me: they pierced my hands and my feet.'

questions.question: What do the enemies do with the Psalmist's garments according to Psalms 22:18?
options: They part my garments among them, and cast lots upon my vesture.
They burn my garments in the fire.
They cover me with my own garments.
They hide my garments in a secret place.
questions.correctAnswer: They part my garments among them, and cast lots upon my vesture.
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:18 describes that the enemies 'part my garments among them, and cast lots upon my vesture.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 22:24 says God hid His face from the afflicted when they cried unto Him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:24 states that God did not hide His face but heard when the afflicted cried unto Him.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 22:27, all the ends of the world shall worship before the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:27 says, 'All the ends of the world shall remember and turn unto the LORD...and all the kindreds of the nations shall worship before thee.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 22:29 states that none can keep alive his own soul.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:29 says, 'none can keep alive his own soul,' confirming the truth of the statement.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 22:10: 'I was cast upon thee from the womb: thou art my ______ from my mother's belly.'
options: God
help
rock
shield
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:10 reads, 'I was cast upon thee from the womb: thou art my God from my mother's belly.'

questions.question: Who will declare God's name unto their brethren according to Psalms 22:22?
options: The Psalmist
The priests
The kings
The prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The Psalmist
questions.explanation: In Psalms 22:22, the Psalmist says, 'I will declare thy name unto my brethren.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 22:21, from what does the Psalmist ask God to save him?
options: The lion's mouth
The flood
The sword of the enemy
The wicked serpents
questions.correctAnswer: The lion's mouth
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:21 states, 'Save me from the lion's mouth: for thou hast heard me from the horns of the unicorns.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 22 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 22 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and feels abandoned by God. Based on Psalms 22, what biblical truth would you share about faith and trust?
options: God hears our cries and delivers us as He did for our fathers.
God always removes us from trials immediately.
We should stop praying if God seems silent.
Our trials mean God has forsaken us permanently.
questions.correctAnswer: God hears our cries and delivers us as He did for our fathers.
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:1-2 shows the psalmist crying out feeling forsaken, yet verses 4-5 remind us that our ancestors trusted God and He delivered them. This encourages steadfast faith and trust during trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 22 teach us about humility in the midst of suffering?
options: Acknowledging our lowliness before God like being 'a worm, and no man'.
Boasting about our strength despite suffering.
Ignoring suffering and pretending all is well.
Blaming others without self-reflection.
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledging our lowliness before God like being 'a worm, and no man'.
questions.explanation: Verse 6 describes the psalmist's humility as he sees himself as 'a worm, and no man'. This teaches believers to approach suffering with humility rather than pride.

questions.question: In dealing with ridicule or scorn from others, what attitude does Psalms 22 suggest we adopt?
options: Trust in the LORD even when others mock your faith.
Retaliate angrily against those who mock.
Avoid people who mock to prevent pain.
Doubt God's care because others laugh.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in the LORD even when others mock your faith.
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 show the psalmist being mocked, yet the passage implies trust in God despite scorn. This encourages believers to maintain faith under ridicule.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed and exhausted in prayer. According to Psalms 22, what encouragement can be drawn about persistence in prayer?
options: Keep crying out to God day and night without silence.
Stop praying if God does not answer immediately.
Only pray during the day when you feel strong.
Prayers are unnecessary during suffering.
questions.correctAnswer: Keep crying out to God day and night without silence.
questions.explanation: Verse 2 teaches that the psalmist cries in the daytime and night, not keeping silent, showing the importance of persistent prayer even in hardship.

questions.question: What does Psalms 22 teach about God's faithfulness from the earliest moments of life?
options: God has cared and made us hope since the womb.
God only cares about us after we become adults.
Our life depends entirely on ourselves, not God.
God forgets us until we seek Him.
questions.correctAnswer: God has cared and made us hope since the womb.
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 emphasize that God took the psalmist from the womb and is his God even from birth, teaching God's lifelong faithfulness and care.

questions.question: How does Psalms 22 encourage believers to respond to intense trials and feelings of abandonment?
options: Request God not to be far and hasten to help.
Give up because no help is near.
Seek help only from people, not God.
Ignore the trouble hoping it will pass.
questions.correctAnswer: Request God not to be far and hasten to help.
questions.explanation: Verse 19 shows the psalmist asking the LORD not to be far and to hasten help, teaching believers to call urgently on God in trials.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 22 teaches that God despises the affliction of the afflicted and hides His face from them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 24 states God has not despised nor abhorred the afflicted and hears their cries, showing His compassion rather than rejection.

questions.question: When sharing the gospel, how does Psalms 22 model declaring God's name and righteousness before others?
options: Proclaiming God's name among brethren and praising Him in congregation.
Keeping faith private and not sharing with others.
Only speaking about God in personal prayer.
Avoiding public declarations to prevent conflict.
questions.correctAnswer: Proclaiming God's name among brethren and praising Him in congregation.
questions.explanation: Verse 22 shows the psalmist declaring God's name to brethren and praising Him publicly, modeling evangelism and worship in community.

questions.question: How does Psalms 22 encourage humility and contentment in daily life?
options: The meek shall eat, be satisfied, and praise the LORD, and their hearts shall live forever.
Only the strong and wealthy will be blessed.
Contentment comes from worldly success.
Pride is necessary to overcome adversity.
questions.correctAnswer: The meek shall eat, be satisfied, and praise the LORD, and their hearts shall live forever.
questions.explanation: Verse 26 teaches that meekness leads to satisfaction and eternal life, encouraging humility and contentment.

questions.question: A believer struggling with fear wants to know how to worship God according to Psalms 22. What advice does this passage offer?
options: Fear the LORD and praise Him, glorify Him with the seed of Israel.
Worship only when you feel joyful.
Avoid worship during hard times.
Worship is unnecessary without perfect faith.
questions.correctAnswer: Fear the LORD and praise Him, glorify Him with the seed of Israel.
questions.explanation: Verse 23 teaches that those who fear the LORD should praise and glorify Him, encouraging reverent worship as a daily practice.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 22 teaches that all nations and peoples will ultimately worship the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 27 states all ends of the world and kindreds shall worship before the LORD, affirming the universal scope of worship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 22 instruct believers on generosity and stewardship through its imagery of provision?
options: All who are 'fat upon earth' shall eat and worship the LORD.
We should keep all our resources to ourselves.
God only blesses those who hoard wealth.
Provision is unrelated to worship.
questions.correctAnswer: All who are 'fat upon earth' shall eat and worship the LORD.
questions.explanation: Verse 29 uses the image of those who are 'fat upon earth' eating and worshiping, linking God’s provision to worship and stewardship.

questions.question: A parent wants to teach their children about faithfulness to God. What example from Psalms 22 supports instructing future generations in righteousness?
options: A seed shall serve Him and declare His righteousness to those born after.
Faith is only personal and not passed down.
Children should learn faith only from outside the family.
Righteousness is irrelevant for new generations.
questions.correctAnswer: A seed shall serve Him and declare His righteousness to those born after.
questions.explanation: Verses 30-31 indicate that future generations will serve God and declare His deeds, encouraging parents to pass on faith.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 22 describes the psalmist’s heart as like _____; it is melted in the midst of his bowels.
options: wax
stone
iron
gold
questions.correctAnswer: wax
questions.explanation: Verse 14 says the heart is like wax, melted in the midst of the bowels, illustrating deep anguish and vulnerability.

questions.question: How does Psalms 22 teach perseverance through spiritual attack and temptation?
options: Calling on God to deliver from the sword, lions, and enemies.
Running away from all challenges without prayer.
Ignoring spiritual attacks hoping they disappear.
Relying only on human strength to overcome.
questions.correctAnswer: Calling on God to deliver from the sword, lions, and enemies.
questions.explanation: Verses 20-21 show the psalmist pleading for deliverance from deadly threats, teaching believers to seek God’s help in spiritual battles.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 22 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 22.

questions.question: In Psalms 22:1, David cries out, 'My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?' This phrase is famously quoted in which New Testament event?
options: Jesus' cry on the cross in Matthew 27:46
Paul's vision in Acts 9
Pentecost in Acts 2
The Transfiguration in Matthew 17
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus' cry on the cross in Matthew 27:46
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:1 is directly quoted by Jesus in Matthew 27:46 as He expresses anguish on the cross, showing the psalm's prophetic foreshadowing.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used throughout Psalms 22, especially seen in verses 6-8 where the speaker describes being scorned and mocked?
options: Parallelism
Chiasmus
Allegory
Metaphor
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The psalm exhibits Hebrew parallelism, repeating ideas in synonymous or antithetic form, as seen in verses 6-8 where reproach and mockery themes are paralleled.

questions.question: In Psalms 22:16, the phrase 'they pierced my hands and my feet' is considered a prophetic foreshadowing of what New Testament event?
options: The crucifixion of Jesus
The anointing of David as king
The Exodus from Egypt
The building of Solomon's temple
questions.correctAnswer: The crucifixion of Jesus
questions.explanation: The piercing of hands and feet in Psalms 22:16 is widely understood as a Messianic prophecy fulfilled in Jesus' crucifixion, where nails pierced his hands and feet.

questions.question: Which phrase in Psalms 22:3 highlights God's holiness and His dwelling among the praises of Israel, emphasizing His sovereign presence?
options: "But thou art holy, O thou that inhabitest the praises of Israel."
"My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?"
"For he hath not despised nor abhorred the affliction of the afflicted."
"The meek shall eat and be satisfied."
questions.correctAnswer: "But thou art holy, O thou that inhabitest the praises of Israel."
questions.explanation: This verse (22:3) expresses God's sanctity and His dwelling among His people’s praises, underscoring His divine presence and authority.

questions.question: The imagery of 'strong bulls of Bashan' in Psalms 22:12 represents what kind of opposition?
options: Powerful and aggressive enemies surrounding the psalmist
Gentle shepherds caring for the flock
Angelic beings protecting the righteous
Foreign kings making treaties
questions.correctAnswer: Powerful and aggressive enemies surrounding the psalmist
questions.explanation: The 'strong bulls of Bashan' symbolize fierce, powerful adversaries besieging the psalmist, invoking cultural knowledge of Bashan's robust cattle.

questions.question: Psalms 22:14 uses the metaphor 'my heart is like wax; it is melted in the midst of my bowels.' What does this metaphor convey about the psalmist's condition?
options: Extreme emotional distress and physical weakness
Joy and celebration
Anger and wrath
Confidence and strength
questions.correctAnswer: Extreme emotional distress and physical weakness
questions.explanation: The melting heart like wax metaphor in 22:14 vividly conveys the psalmist’s overwhelming anguish and loss of strength.

questions.question: The phrase 'they part my garments among them, and cast lots upon my vesture' in Psalms 22:18 is paralleled in which New Testament event?
options: Roman soldiers casting lots for Jesus’ clothing at the crucifixion
The anointing of Solomon as king
The feeding of the 5000
Paul’s shipwreck on Malta
questions.correctAnswer: Roman soldiers casting lots for Jesus’ clothing at the crucifixion
questions.explanation: This verse foreshadows the Roman soldiers dividing Jesus’ garments and casting lots during his crucifixion (John 19:23-24).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 22:24 reveals that God hides His face from those who cry to Him in affliction.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 22:24 explicitly states God does not hide His face but hears those who cry to Him in their affliction.

questions.question: What is the significance of the term 'Aijeleth Shahar' in the superscription of Psalms 22:1, often translated as 'hind of the dawn' or 'doe of the morning'?
options: It indicates a musical or liturgical tune for the psalm
It refers to a historical battle
It denotes the author’s lineage
It is the name of a temple
questions.correctAnswer: It indicates a musical or liturgical tune for the psalm
questions.explanation: The term 'Aijeleth Shahar' is understood as a musical direction or tune to which this psalm was to be sung, reflecting ancient worship practices.

questions.question: In Psalms 22:21, the psalmist asks to be saved 'from the horns of the unicorns.' Considering the Hebrew term 're'em,' which animal is most likely referenced here in ancient Near Eastern context?
options: A wild ox or a powerful horned animal
A mythical unicorn as understood today
A lion
A mountain goat
questions.correctAnswer: A wild ox or a powerful horned animal
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 're'em' likely refers to a wild ox or a strong horned animal symbolic of strength and danger, not a mythical unicorn.

questions.question: According to Psalms 22:4-5, what is the basis of the fathers’ confidence and their deliverance?
options: Their trust in God and His deliverance
Their military strength
Their wealth and alliances
Their wisdom and counsel
questions.correctAnswer: Their trust in God and His deliverance
questions.explanation: Verses 4-5 emphasize that the ancestors trusted in God and were delivered, highlighting faith as the foundation of their salvation.

questions.question: Which theme is developed in Psalms 22:26-28 that reflects a universal acknowledgment of God's sovereignty?
options: All nations will worship and recognize the LORD’s kingdom
Only Israel will be saved
God’s judgment is limited to Judah
The psalmist will rule over other nations
questions.correctAnswer: All nations will worship and recognize the LORD’s kingdom
questions.explanation: Verses 26-28 declare that all peoples and ends of the earth will turn to worship the LORD, affirming His universal kingship.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe his physical state in Psalms 22:15, and what might this signify in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Strength dried up like a potsherd; tongue cleaving to jaws, signifying extreme dehydration and near death
Strong and victorious like a lion
Healthy and blessed by God
Calm and peaceful like still waters
questions.correctAnswer: Strength dried up like a potsherd; tongue cleaving to jaws, signifying extreme dehydration and near death
questions.explanation: The metaphor of dried strength and tongue sticking to jaws reflects severe physical suffering and distress common in ancient descriptions of dying.

questions.question: In Psalms 22:30-31, what does the 'seed' represent, and how does this relate to the continuity of faith?
options: Future generations who will serve God and declare His righteousness
Agricultural produce
The psalmist’s personal descendants only
A symbolic reference to trees
questions.correctAnswer: Future generations who will serve God and declare His righteousness
questions.explanation: The 'seed' symbolizes successive generations who will continue worship and proclaim God's deeds, emphasizing faith’s perpetuity.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 22 is structured as a lament that transitions into a song of praise and hope.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The psalm begins with despair and lament (verses 1-21) and moves to praise and hope (verses 22-31), demonstrating a classic lament-to-praise structure.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 22 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 22 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the initial cry of the psalmist that expresses a deep sense of abandonment by God?
options: My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?
The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want.
Be still, and know that I am God.
The earth is the LORD's, and the fulness thereof.
questions.correctAnswer: My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?
questions.explanation: Psalm 22:1 opens with the psalmist's profound lament of feeling forsaken by God. This cry is echoed by Jesus on the cross (Matthew 27:46), aligning the psalm with messianic suffering and illustrating human despair in divine silence.

questions.question: According to Psalm 22, how does the psalmist describe God's dwelling?
options: In the praises of Israel
On the mountain of the LORD
In the temple of holiness
Among the cherubim
questions.correctAnswer: In the praises of Israel
questions.explanation: Psalm 22:3 highlights God's holiness and His inhabiting the praises of Israel, emphasizing worship as God's dwelling place. This aligns with Hebrews 13:15 where praise is a sacrifice acceptable to God.

questions.question: What metaphor does the psalmist use to describe his own condition in Psalm 22:6?
options: A worm, and no man
A lion among sheep
A tree planted by the rivers of water
A stone rejected by builders
questions.correctAnswer: A worm, and no man
questions.explanation: In verse 6, the psalmist portrays himself as utterly lowly and despised, 'a worm, and no man.' This metaphor reveals human frailty and rejection, resonating with Isaiah 41:14 and the humility of Christ in Philippians 2:7.

questions.question: Who are described as surrounding the psalmist like 'strong bulls of Bashan'?
options: Many bulls
Eagles of the sky
Enemies of the city
False prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Many bulls
questions.explanation: Psalm 22:12 uses the imagery of 'many bulls' and 'strong bulls of Bashan' to symbolize powerful adversaries besetting the psalmist, illustrating overwhelming opposition similar to the enemies of God's people in 1 Samuel 17:34-36.

questions.question: What physical suffering is vividly described in Psalm 22:14?
options: I am poured out like water, and all my bones are out of joint
My eyes are flooded with tears
My hands tremble like a leaf
My feet are swift to run
questions.correctAnswer: I am poured out like water, and all my bones are out of joint
questions.explanation: Verse 14 graphically depicts physical agony and weakness, conveying the psalmist's intense distress. This foreshadows Christ's suffering on the cross (Isaiah 53:12) and Paul's description of bodily affliction in 2 Corinthians 12:7-10.

questions.question: What action do the 'assembly of the wicked' perform according to Psalm 22:18?
options: They part my garments among them, and cast lots upon my vesture
They raise their voices in blasphemy
They build altars to false gods
They bind the hands of the innocent
questions.correctAnswer: They part my garments among them, and cast lots upon my vesture
questions.explanation: Psalm 22:18 describes the enemies dividing the psalmist's clothing and casting lots, a detail that is explicitly fulfilled in the New Testament during Christ's crucifixion (John 19:23-24), affirming the messianic nature of this psalm.

questions.question: In Psalm 22:21, from what does the psalmist ask God to save him?
options: The lion's mouth
The pit of destruction
The hands of the oppressor
The storms of the sea
questions.correctAnswer: The lion's mouth
questions.explanation: The psalmist pleads in verse 21 for deliverance from the 'lion's mouth,' symbolizing imminent danger and death, paralleling God's deliverance of David from lions (1 Samuel 17:37) and the believer's ultimate rescue in Psalm 91:13.

questions.question: How does the psalmist express his intent concerning God's name in Psalm 22:22?
options: I will declare thy name unto my brethren
I will keep silent and meditate
I will whisper thy name in the night
I will write thy name upon the tablets of my heart
questions.correctAnswer: I will declare thy name unto my brethren
questions.explanation: Verse 22 reveals the psalmist's commitment to proclaim God's name publicly and praise Him among the congregation, which aligns with the New Testament emphasis on witness (Acts 1:8) and communal worship (Hebrews 10:25).

questions.question: According to Psalm 22:24, how does God respond to the afflicted when they cry to Him?
options: He hears them and does not hide His face
He delays and tests their faith
He sends immediate judgment
He remains silent
questions.correctAnswer: He hears them and does not hide His face
questions.explanation: Psalm 22:24 affirms God's compassion and attentiveness to the suffering, confirming His faithfulness. This is consistent with Psalm 34:17 and 2 Corinthians 1:3-4 where God comforts the afflicted.

questions.question: What promise is made in Psalm 22:26 regarding the meek who seek the LORD?
options: They shall eat and be satisfied and their heart shall live forever
They shall inherit the earth and reign
They shall be hidden in the shadow of the Almighty
They shall receive the crown of life
questions.correctAnswer: They shall eat and be satisfied and their heart shall live forever
questions.explanation: Verse 26 promises sustenance and eternal life to the meek who seek God, reflecting the blessings in Matthew 5:5 and John 6:35 where spiritual satisfaction and eternal life are assured through Christ.

questions.question: What universal eschatological vision is depicted in Psalm 22:27?
options: All the ends of the world shall remember and turn unto the LORD
The heavens and earth shall be renewed
The wolf shall dwell with the lamb
The sun shall be darkened and the moon turned to blood
questions.correctAnswer: All the ends of the world shall remember and turn unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 27 presents a global recognition and worship of God, an eschatological hope echoed in Isaiah 45:22 and Revelation 7:9 where all nations worship the Lord, highlighting God's sovereign reign over all creation.

questions.question: What does Psalm 22:28 declare about God's sovereignty?
options: The kingdom is the LORD's and He is governor among the nations
God dwells in unapproachable light
The LORD is a sun and shield
He rides upon the heavens as a warrior
questions.correctAnswer: The kingdom is the LORD's and He is governor among the nations
questions.explanation: Verse 28 affirms God's universal kingship and governance, consistent with Daniel 4:3 and 1 Timothy 6:15 which proclaim God's supreme authority over all earthly powers and nations.

questions.question: What is the psalmist's description of those who are 'fat upon earth' in Psalm 22:29?
options: They shall eat and worship
They shall be cast down and forgotten
They shall rule over the poor
They shall be filled with pride
questions.correctAnswer: They shall eat and worship
questions.explanation: Verse 29 depicts even the prosperous as ultimately submitting in worship to God, illustrating God's rightful dominion. This is echoed in Philippians 2:10-11 where every knee bows to Christ.

questions.question: What future generational service to the LORD is promised in Psalm 22:30?
options: A seed shall serve Him and be accounted for a generation
The descendants shall build His temple
Kings shall rise from His lineage
His covenant shall be written on their hearts
questions.correctAnswer: A seed shall serve Him and be accounted for a generation
questions.explanation: Verse 30 promises that future generations will serve God, reflecting covenantal faithfulness and continuity seen in Genesis 17:7 and Acts 2:39, emphasizing God's enduring plan of salvation.

questions.question: What is the psalmist's declaration about God's righteousness in Psalm 22:31?
options: They shall declare His righteousness to a people yet to be born
His righteousness is everlasting and unchanging
His righteousness delivers from sin and death
His righteousness is a shield to the faithful
questions.correctAnswer: They shall declare His righteousness to a people yet to be born
questions.explanation: Verse 31 anticipates future proclamation of God's righteous acts to unborn generations, highlighting the ongoing revelation of God's salvation plan, as affirmed in Psalm 78:4 and Romans 1:16.
